availability.p: Downloading shall be restricted to one copy for private use.

monogr.author: Unknown
monogr.title: Four Romances of England: King Horn, Havelok the Dane, Bevis of Hampton, Athelston

projectDesc.p: The Middle English Texts Series offers a diverse and representative array of literary texts that medieval readers in the present-day British Isles would have encountered between the twelfth and sixteenth centuries. It is committed to making available both affordable print and open access editions to scholars, teachers, and students of the Western Middle Ages. In its digital publications, the series prioritizes a user-friendly interface and viewing options, multiple downloadable formats, enhanced searchability and filtering, and accessibility to the widest possible range of users.

editorialDecl.p: METS takes as its mission the creation of affordable editions that would pass scrutiny from the most demanding expert, yet would prove comprehensible, and even enticing, to someone who had never read Middle English before. This agenda dictates that METS publications offer not a critical edition reflecting all surviving manuscripts, and certainly not a diplomatic edition, but a best-text edition, informed by the notes and apparatus of earlier editions (where these exist), and by substantive variants from other manuscript witnesses. Transcriptions of Middle English texts are lightly modernized to ensure a smooth reading experience, while non-English texts preserve both the original language and a modern English translation in facing-page format. Each edition offers expert assistance with language and lexicon, providing glosses alongside the text(s), textual and explanatory notes, elucidation of unfamiliar contexts and traditions, and thematic and interpretive possibilities. All editions feature general introductions that set the edited text within its own time, place, and traditions, and link it to ancestor, congener, and successor materials. All publications contain comprehensive, current bibliographies of pertinent scholarship and criticism. House style is adapted from the Chicago Manual of Style.

correction.p: This text may include corrections made after the original edition went to press in order to correct errors and improve glosses. For a full list of editorial and typographical corrections made to this edition, please view its correction log on Github: https://github.com/mets-editions/herzman-fourromances/blob/main/herzman-fourromances-export-corrections-log.xlsx

lg.l: Lord that is off myghtys most,Gpowers greatest
Fadyr and Sone and Holy Gost,
Bryng us out of synne
And leneG us grace so for to wyrkegrant
To love bothe God and Holy KyrkeGChurch
That we may hevene wynne.N T
Lystnes, lordyngys, that ben hende,Ggracious
OfT falsnesse, hou it wil endeGwill bring about an end to
A man that ledes hymG therin.N a man [who] leads himself
Of foure weddydG bretherynN I wole yow tellsworn
That wolden yn Yngelond go dwel,N
That sybbeG were nought of kyn.Grelative family
And all foure messangeres they were,
That wolden yn Yngelond lettrys bere,
As it wes here kynde.Gtheir occupation
By a forest ganG they meteGdid meet
With a cros, stood in a streteN Gby a road
Be leffG undyr a lynde,GBy a leaf linden (tree)
And, as the story telles me,
YlkeG man was of dyversG cuntré,Each different
In book iwreten we fyndeN —
For love of hereG metyng thare,their
They swoor hemG weddyd bretheryn for evermare,themselves
In trewtheG trewely dede hem bynde.an oath
The eldeste of hem ylkon,Gthem all
He was hyghtG Athelston,N called
The kyngys cosyn dere;
He was of the kyngys blood,Ga [blood] relative
Hys eemesG sone, I undyrstood;uncle’s
Therefore he neyghydG hym nere.N approached
And at the laste, weelG and fayr,well
The kyng him dyydG withouten ayr.Gdied heir
Thenne was ther non hys pereGequal
But Athelston, hys eemesG sone;uncle’s
To make hym kyng wolde they nought schone,Grefuse (shun)
To corowne hym with gold so clere.
Now was he kyng semelyG to se:handsome
He sendes afftyr his bretherynG thre[sworn] brothers
And gaff hem here warysoun.Gthem their reward
The eldest brothir he made Eerl of DovereN —
And thus the pore man gan covereG —recover
Lord of tourG and toun.tower
That other brother he made Eerl of StaneN G —Stone
Egelond was hys name,
A man of gret renoun —
And gaff him tylG hys weddyd wyffto be
Hys owne sustyr, Dame Edyff,N
With gret devocyoun.
The fertheG brothir was a clerk,Gfourth cleric
MekylG he cowdeG of Goddys werk.Much knew
Hys name it was Alryke.
Cauntyrbury was vacant
And fel into that kyngys hand;
He gaff it hym that wyke,Goffice
And made hym bysschop of that stede,Gplace
That noble clerk, on book cowde redeN —
In the world was non hym lyche.Glike
Thus avaunsydG he hys brother thorwgh Goddys gras,Gadvanced grace
And Athelston hymselven was
A good kyng and a ryche.Gpowerful
And he that was Eerl of Stane —
Sere Egeland was hys name —
Was trewe, as ye schal here.
Thorwgh the myght off Goddys gras,Ggrace
He gatG upon the countasGbegat countess
Twoo knave-chyldrenG dere.boys
That on was fyfftene wyntyrG old,N years
That other thryttene, as men me told:
In the world was non here pereG —their equal
Also whyt so lylye-flour,GAs white as [a] lily flower
Red as rose off here colour,
As bryght as blosme on brere.Gbriar
Bothe the Eerl and hys wyff,
The kyng hem lovede as hys lyff,
And hereG sones twoo;their
And offtensytheG he gan hem calleoften-times
Bothe to boureG and to halle,N inner chamber
To counsayl whenne they scholde goo.
Therat Sere Wymound hadde gret envye,
That Eerle of Dovere, wyttyrlye.Gcertainly
In herte he was ful woo.Gaggrieved
He thoughte al for here sakeGon their account
False lesyngysG on hem to make,lies
To don hem brenne and sloo.N Gcause them [to be] burned and slain
And thanne Sere Wymound hym bethoughte:Gthought to himself
“HereG love thus endure may noughte;Their
Thorwgh wurdG oure werk may sprynge.”GThrough word advance
He bad hys men maken hem yare;Gready
Unto Londone wolde he fareGgo
To speke with the kynge.
Whenne that he to Londone come,
He mette with the kyng ful sone.Gright away
He sayde, “Welcome, my derelyng.”Gfriend
The kyng hym fraynyd seone anon,Gquestioned soon
By what way he hadde igon,
Withouten ony dwellyng.Gdelaying
“Come thou ought by Cauntyrbury,
ThereG the clerkys syngen meryN Where
Bothe erly and late?N
Hou faryth that noble clerk,
That mekyl can onG Goddys werk?N much knows of
Knowest thou ought hys state?Gwhat his condition is
And come thou ought beG the Eerl of Stane,by
That wurthy lord in hys wane?Gresidence
Wente thou oughtG that gate?Gout of way
Hou fares that noble knyght,
And hys sones fayr and bryght
My sustyr, yiffG that thou wate?”Gif know
“Sere,” thanne he sayde, “withouten les,Gfalsehood
Be Cauntyrbery my way I ches;Gchose
ThereG spak I with that dere.GWhere dear [person]
Ryght weel gretes thee that noble clerk,
That mykyl canG of Goddys werk;knows much
In the world is non hys pere.Gequal
And also be Stane my way I drowgh;Gtook
With Egelond I spak inowgh,Genough
And with the countesse so clere.Gbeautiful
They fare weel,G is nought to layne,Gwell nothing to conceal
And bothe hereG sones.” The king was fayneGtheir happy
And in his herte made glad chere.
“Sere kyng,” he saide, “yiff it be thi wille
To chaumbyr that thou woldest wenden tylle,Ggo to
Consayl for to here,
I schal thee telle a swete tydande,Greport
There comen nevere non swycheG in this landesuch
Of all this hundryd yere.”
The kyngys herte than was ful wooGsad
With that traytour for to goo;
They wente bothe forth in fere;Gtogether
And whenne that they were the chaumbyr withinne,
False lesyngysG he gan begynneGlies began
On hys weddyd brother dere.
“Sere kyng,” he saide, “woo were me,
DedG that I scholdeG see thee,Dead [it] should
So moot IG have my lyff!As I may
For by Hym that al this worlN wan,Gworld redeemed
Thou has makyd me a man,
And iholpeG me for to thryff.Ghelped thrive
For in thy land, sere, is a fals traytour.T
He wole doo thee mykylG dyshonourmuch
And brynge thee of lyve.Gkill you
He wole deposenT theeG slyly,depose you
SodaynlyG than schalt thou dySuddenly
By Chrystys woundys fyve!”
Thenne sayde the kyng, “So mootG thou the,N Gmight thrive
Knowe I that man, and IG hym see?if I
His name thou me telle.”
“Nay,” says that traytour, “that wole I nought
For al the gold that evere was wrought —
Be masse-book and belleN —
But yiffG thou me thy trowtheG will plyghtGUnless vow pledge
That thou schalt nevere bewreyeG the knyghtbetray
That theeG the tale schal telle.”[to] you
Thanne the kyng his hand up raughte,N Graised
That false man his trowthe betaughte,N Gfaith entrusted
He was a devyl of helle!
“Sere kyng,” he sayde, “thou madyst me knyght,
And now thou hast thy trowthe me plyghtGpledged
Oure counsayl for to layne:Gconceal
Sertaynly, it is non othir
But Egelane, thy weddyd brothir —
He woldeG that thou were slayne;wishes
He dos thy sustyr to undyrstand
He wole be kyng of thy lande,
And thus he begynnes here trayne.Gto lead her astray
He wole thee poysoun ryght slyly;N
Sodaynly thanne schalt thou dy,
By Him that suffryd payne.”
Thanne swoor the kyng be Cros and Roode:GCross
“MeeteG ne drynk schal do me goode[Neither] food
Tyl that he be dede;
Bothe he and hys wyf, hys soones twoo,
Schole they nevere be no moo
In Yngelond on that stede.”N Gplace
“Nay,” says the traytour, “so moot I the,Gthrive
Ded wole I nought my brother se;N
But do thy beste rede.”Gadvice
No lengere there then wolde he lende;Gremain
He takes hys leve, to Dovere gan wende.Gbegan to go
God geve hym schame and dede!Gdeath
Now is that traytour hom iwent.
A messanger was afftyrG sentafterward
To speke with the kyng.
I weneG he barG his owne name:believe bore
He was hotenG Athelstane;N called
He was foundelyng.Ga foundling
The lettrys were imaad fullyche thare,Gfully there
Unto Stane for to fareGgo
Withouten ony dwellyng,Gdelaying
To fetteG the eerl and his sones twoo,fetch
And the countasse alsoo,
Dame Edyve, that swete thyng.
And in the lettre yitG was it tolde,also
That the kyng the eerlys sones wolde
Make hem bothe knyght;
And therto his seelG he sette.seal
The messanger wolde nought lette;Gdelay
The way he rydes ful ryght.
The messanger, the noble man,
Takes hys hors and forth he wan,Gwent
And hyesG a ful good spede.hastens
The eerl in hys halle he fande;Gfound
He took hym the lettre in his hande
Anon he badG hym rede:bade
“Sere,” he sayde also swythe,Gquickly
“This lettre oughte to make thee blythe:Gglad
Thertoo thou take good hede.Gheed
The kyng wole for the cuntasG sakecountess’
Bothe thy sones knyghtes makeN —
To London I redeG thee spede.Gadvise hurry
The kyng wole for the cuntas sake
Bothe thy sones knyghtes make,
The blythereG thou may be.happier
Thy fayre wyff with thee thou bryng —
And ther be ryght no lettyngG —delaying
That syghte that sche may see.”
Thenne sayde that eerl with herte mylde,
“My wyff goth ryght gret with chylde,
And forthynkes me,GI regret [that]
Sche may nought out of chaumbyr wyn,Ggo
To speke with non endeG of here kynno part
Tyl sche delyveryd be.”
But into chaumbyr they gunne wende,Gbegan to go
To rede the lettrys before that hendeGcourteous lady
And tydingys tolde here soone.
Thanne sayde the cuntasse, “So moot I the,Gthrive
I wil nought letteG tyl I there be,stop
Tomorwen orG it be noone.before
To see hem knyghtes, my sones fre,Gnoble
I wole nought lette tyl I there be;
I schal no lengere dwelle.Gdelay
Cryst foryeldeG my lord the kyng,requite
That has grauntyd hem here dubbyng.Gtheir dubbing
Myn herte is gladyd welle.”
The eerl hys men bad make hem yare;Gready
He and hys wyff forth gunne they fare,Gbegan to go
To London faste they wente.
At WestemynstyrN was the kyngys wone;Gdwelling
There they mette with Athelstone,
ThatG afftyr hem hadde sente.Who
The goode eerl soone was hentGseized
And feterydG faste, verrayment,Gchained truly
And hys sones twoo.
Ful lowde the countasse gan to crye,
And sayde, “Goode brothir, mercy!
Why wole ye us sloo?Gslay
What have we ayensG yow done,against
That ye wole have us ded so soone?
Me thynkith ye arn ourn foo.”Genemy
The kyng as wood ferdeG in that stede;Ginsane behaved place
He garteG hys sustyr to presoun lede —ordered
In herte he was ful woo.
Thenne a squyer, was the countasses frende,Gfriend
To the qwene he gan wende,Gdid go
And tydyngys tolde here soone.
Gerlondes of chyryesN G offG sche caste,Garlands of cherries off
Into the halle sche come at the laste,
Longe orG it were noone.before
“Sere kyng, I am before thee come
With a child, doughtyr or a sone.
Graunte me my bone,Grequest
My brothir and sustyr that I may borweGact as surety for
Tyl the nexte day at morwe,
Out of here paynysG stronge;pain
That we mowe wete by comoun sentGmight know by unanimous assent
In the playne parlement.”T
“Dame,” he saide, “goo fro me!
Thy boneG shall nought igraunted be,request (boon)
I doo thee to undyrstande.
For, beG Hym that weresG the corowne of thorn,by wears
They schole be drawen and hangyd tomorn,
Yyff I be kyng of lande!”
And whenne the qwene these wurdes herde,
As sche hadde beG beten with yerde,Gbeen stick
The teeres sche leetG doun falle.let
Sertaynly, as I yow telle,
On here bare knees doun she felle,
And prayde yit for hem alle.
“A, dame,” he sayde, “verraymentGtruly
Hast thou brokeG my comaundement[If] you have broken
AbyydN G ful dere thou schalle.”Pay for
With hys foot — he wolde nought wondeG —refrain
He slowghG the chyld ryght in hereG wombe;N slew her
She swownydG amonges hem alle.swooned
Ladyys and maydenys that there were,
The qwene to here chaumbyr bere,Gbore
And there was dool inowgh.Gdole (sorrow) enough
Soone withinne a lytyl spaseGspace of time
A knave-chyld ibornG ther wase,N miscarried
As bryght as blosme on bowgh.
He was bothe whyt and red;N
Of that dyntG was he dedG —From that blow dead
His owne fadyr hym slowgh!Gslew
Thus may a traytour baretN rayseGstrife raise
And make manye men ful evele at ayse,Gill at ease
Hymselff nought afftyrG it lowgh.N Gafter laughed
But yit the qwene, as ye schole here,
Sche callyd upon a messangere,
Bad hym a lettre fonge.Gtake
And bad hym wendeG to Cauntyrbery,go
ThereG the clerkys syngen meryWhere
Bothe masse and evensonge.
“This lettre thou the bysschop take,
And praye hym for Goddys sake,
Come boreweG hem out off here bande.Grescue bonds
He wole doo more for hym, I wene,Gbelieve
Thanne for me, though I be qwene —
I doo thee to undyrstande.
An eerldom in SpayneN I have of land;
Al I seseG into thyn hand,give as a possession
Trewely, as I thee hyght,Gpromise
And hundryd besauntysN G of gold red.besant (a coin)
Thou may save hem from the ded,Gdeath
Yyff that thyn hors be wyght.”Gvaliant
“Madame, broukeG weel thy moregeve,N Guse morning gift
Also longe as thou may leve.Glive
Therto have I no ryght.
But of thy gold and of thy fee,Gproperty
Cryst in hevene foryeldeG it thee;reward
I wole be there tonyght.
Madame, thrytty mylesG of hard waythirty miles
I have reden sythG it was day.since
Ful sore I gan me swynke;Gwork
And for to ryde now fyve and twenti thertooN
An hard thyng it were to doo,
Forsothe, ryght as me thynke.
Madame, it is nerhande passyd prime,Gnearly past six a.m.
And me behoves al for to dyne,
Bothe wyn and ale to drynke.
Whenne I have dynyd, thenne wole I fare.N
God may covereG hem of hereG care,relieve their
OrG that I slepe a wynke.”Before
Whenne he hadde dynyd, he wente his way,
Also faste as that he may,
He rod be Charynge-crossN GCharing Cross
And entryd into Flete-streteN GFleet Street
And sithen thorwgh Londone, I yow hete,Gpromise
Upon a noble hors.
The messanger, that noble man,
On Loundone-bryggeN G sone he wanG —London bridge reached
For his travayleG he hadde no losN G —work praise (fame)
From Stone into Steppyngebourne,N
Forsothe, his way nolde he nought tourne;Gnot alter
Sparyd he nought for myre ne mos.T Gmud nor bog
And thus hys way wendes he
Fro Osprynge to the Blee.N
Thenne myghte he see the toun
Of Cauntyrbery, that noble wyke,Gplace
Therin lay that bysschop ryke,N Gpowerful
That lord of gret renoun.
And whenne they runggen undernbelle,Gmorning bell
He rod in Londone, as I yow telle:
He was non erG redy;earlier
And yit to Cauntyrbery he wan,Greached
Longe or evensongG began;before six p.m.
He rod mylys fyffty.Gfifty miles
The messanger nothing abod;Gdelayed
Into the palays forth he rod,
There that the bysschop was inne.
Ryght welcome was the messanger,
That was come from the qwene so cleer,Gradiant
Was of so noble kynne.
He took hym a lettre fulG good speedsuch
And saide, “Sere bysschop, haveG this and reed,”N Gtake read
And bad hym come with hym.
OrG he the lettre hadde halff iredde,GBefore read
For dool,G hym thoughte hys herte bledde;sorrow
The teeres fyl ovyr hys chyn.Gchin
The bysschop bad sadele hys palfray:N
“AlsoG faste as thay may,As
Bydde my men make hem yare;Gthemselves ready
And wendes before,”G the bysschop dede say,go before
“To my maneresG in the way;manors
For nothyng that ye spare,
And loke at ylkeG fyve mylys endeeach
A fresch hors that I fynde,
SchodG and nothing bare;Shod
Blythe schal I nevere be,
Tyl I my weddyd brother see,
To kevereG hym out of care.”recover
On nyneG palfrays the bysschop sprong,nine
ArG it was day, from evensong —Before
In romaunce as we rede.
Sertaynly, as I yow telle,
On Londone-brygge dedG doun felledead
The messangeres stede.Gmessenger’s horse
“Allas,” he sayde, “that I was born!
Now is my goode hors forlorn,Gutterly lost
Was good at ylke a nede;Gat each need
Yistyrday upon the grounde,
He was wurth an hundryd pounde,N
Ony kyng to lede.”
Thenne bespak the erchebysschop.Garchbishop
Oure gostlyG fadyr undyr God,N spiritual
Unto the messangere:
“Lat be thy menyngG of thy stede,GDesist your lamenting horse
And thynk upon oure mykyl nede,Ggreat need
The whylys that we ben here;
For yiff that I may my brother borweGsave
And bryngen hym out off mekylG sorwe,great
Thou may make glad chere;
And thy warysounG I schal thee geve,reward
AndG God have grauntyd thee to leveEven if
Unto an hundryd yere.”N
The bysschop thenne nought ne bod:Gremained no longer
He took hys hors, and forth he rod
Into Westemynstyr so lyght;N Gnimbly
The messanger on his foot alsoo:
With the bysschop come no moo,Gno others
Nether squyer ne knyght.
Upon the morwen the kyng aros,
And takes the way, to the kyrkeN G he gos,church
As man of mekyl myght.
With hym wente bothe preest and clerk,
That mykyl cowdeG of Goddys werk,Who knew much
To praye God for the ryght.
Whenne that he to the kyrke com;
Tofore the RodeG he knelyd anon,Cross
And on hys knees he felle:
“God, that syt in Trynyté
A boneG that thou graunte me,boon (i.e., favor)
Lord, as Thou harewydG helle —harrowed
GyltlessG men yiff thayG be,T Guiltless if they
That are in my presoun free,N
ForcursydG there to yelle,GCondemned shriek
Of the gylt andG thay be clene,Gif innocent
LeveG it moot on hem be sene,GGrant seen [by them]
That garte hem there to dwelle.”GWho made them to dwell there
And whenne he hadde maad his prayer,
He lokyd up into the qweer;Gchoir
The erchebysschop sawgh he stande.
He was forwondryd ofG that caas,Gastonished at situation
And to hym he wente apas,Gquickly
And took hym beG the hande.Gby hand
“Welcome,” he sayde, “thou erchebysschop,
Oure gostlyG fadyr undyr God.”spiritual
He swoor beG God levande,N Gby living
“Weddyd brother, weel moot thou spede,Gprosper
For I hadde nevere so mekyl nede,
SithG I took cros on hande.Since
Goode weddyd brother, now turne thy rede;Gchange your mind
Doo nought thyn owne blood to dedeG[cause] to die
But yiffG it wurthy were.Unless
For Hym that weres the corowne of thorn,
Lat me borweG hem tyl tomorn,be surety for
That we mowe enquere,Gmight have an inquiry
And wetenG alle be comoun asentGknow agreement
In the playneG parlementT full
Who is wurthy be schent.Gpunished
And, but yiff ye wole graunte my bone,
It schal us rewe botheG or none,Ggrieve us both before noon
Be God that alle thyng lent.”Ggave
Thanne the kyng wax wrotheG as wynde,Ggrew angry wind
A wodereG man myghte no man fyndeAn angrier
Than he began to bee:
He swoor othis beG sunne and mone:N Goaths by moon
“They scholen be drawen and hongyd or noneG —before noon
With eyenG thou schalt see!eyes
Lay doun thy cros and thy staff,
Thy mytyrG and thy ryng that I thee gaff;N mitre
Out of my land thou flee!
HygheG thee faste out of my syght!Get
Wher I thee mete, thy deth is dyght;Gdecided
Non othir then schal it bee!”
Thenne bespak that erchebysschop,N
Oure gostlyG fadyr undyr God,spiritual
SmertlyG to the kyng:Sharply
“Weel I wotG that thou me gaffknow
Bothe the cros and the staff,
The mytyr and ekeG the ryng;N also
My bysschoprycheG thou revesG me,bishopric deny
And Crystyndom forbedeG I thee!N forbid
Preest schal ther non syngge;
Neyther maydynchyldG ne knaveGgirl boy
Crystyndom schal ther non have;
To care I schal thee brynge.
I schal gare cryeG thorwgh ylke a tounproclaim
That kyrkysG schole be broken dounchurches
And stokenG agayn with thorn.stuck
And thou shalt lyggeG in an old dyke,N Glie ditch
As itG were an heretyke,Gif you heretic
Allas that thou were born!
Yiff thou be ded, that I may see,
AssoylydG schalt thou nevere bee;Absolved
Thanne is thy soule in sorwe.
And I schal wendeG in uncoutheG lond,go unknown
And gete me stronge men of hond;
My brothir yit schal I borwe.Gsave
I schal brynge upon thy lond
Hungyr and thyrst ful strong,
Cold, drougthe, and sorwe;
I schal nought leveG on thy londleave
WurthG the gloves on thy hondWorth
To begge ne to borwe.”N
The bysschop has his leve tan.Gleave taken
By that his men were comen ylkan:Geach one
They sayden, “Sere, have good day.”
He entryd into Flete-strete;
With lordys of Yngelond gan he mete
Upon a noble aray.
On here knees they kneleden adoun,
And prayden hym of hys benysoun,Gblessing
He nykkyd hem with nay.Grefused them by saying no
Neyther of cros neyther of ryng
Hadde they non kyns wetyng;Gkind of knowing
And thanne a knyght gan say.Gbegan to speak
A knyght thanne spak with mylde voys:Gmild voice
“Sere, where is thy ryng? Where is thy croys?Gcross
Is it fro thee tan?”Gtaken
Thanne he sayde, “Youre cursyd kyng
Hath me refftG of al my thyng,bereft
And of al my worldly wan;Ggoods
And I have entyrdytydT Yngelond:Ginterdicted England
Ther schal no preest synge MasseG with hond,celebrate Mass
Chyld schal be crystenyd non,GNo child shall be christened
But yiffG he graunte meG that knyght,Unless release to me
His wyff and chyldryn fayr and bryght:N
He wolde with wrong hem slon.”Gslay
The knyght sayde, “Bysschop, turne agayn;
Of thy body we are ful fayn;Gglad
Thy brothir yit schole we borwe.Grescue
And, but he graunte us oure bone,
Hys presoun schal be brokenG soone,violated
Hymselff to mekylG sorwe.[driven] to great
We schole drawe doun both halle and boures,Gchambers
Bothe hys castelles and hys toures,
They schole lygge loweG and holewe.razed
Though he be kyng and wereG the corown,wear
We scholen hym sette in a deep dunjoun:Gdungeon
Oure Crystyndom we wole folewe.”
Thanne, as they spoken of this thyng,
Ther comen twoo knyghtes from the kyng,
And sayden, “Bysschop, abyde,Gwait
And have thy cros and thy ryng,
And welcome whyl that thou wylt lyng,Gstay
It is nought for to hyde.
Here he grauntys thee the knyght,
Hys wyff and chyldryn fayr and bryght;
Again I rede thou ryde.Gadvise you return
He prayes thee pur charytéGby pure charity
That he myghte asoylydG be,absolved
And Yngelond long and wyde.”
HereofG the bysschop was ful fayn,GOf this eager
And turnys hys brydyl and wendes agayn —
Barouns gunneG with hym ryde —did
Unto the Brokene-crosN of ston;
Thedyr com the kyng ful soone anon,
And there he gan abyde.
Upon hys knees he knelyd adoun,
And prayde the bysschop of benysoun,Gfor blessing
And he gaff hymG that tyde.gave it to him
With holy watyr and orysoun,Gprayer
He asoylydG the kyng that werydG the coroun,absolved who wore
And Yngelond long and wyde.
Than sayde the kyng anon ryght:
“Here I graunte thee that knyght,
And hys sones free,Gnoble
And my sustyr hendeG in halle.courteous
Thou hast savyd here lyvysG alle:their lives
Iblessyd moot thou bee.”
Thenne sayde the bysschop also soone:
“And I schal geven swylke a domeG —judgment
With eyen that thou schalt see!Gyour own eyes
Yiff thay be gylty off that dede,
SorrereG the doome thay may drede,More grievous
Thanne schewe here schame to me.”
Whanne the bysschop hadde sayd soo,
A gret fyrG was maad ryght thoo,Gfire immediately
In romaunce as we rede —
It was set, that men myghte knawe,Gknow
Nyne plowgh-lengtheG on rawe,N Gploughshares in a row
As red as ony glede.Gcoal
Thanne sayde the kyng: “What may this mene?”
“Sere, ofG gylt andG thay be clene,Gfrom if innocent
This doomN G hem thar nought drede.”Gordeal need not fear
Thanne sayde the good Kyng Athelston:
“An hard doomeG now is this on:Gjudgment one
God graunte us alle weel to spede.”Gsucceed
They fettenG forth Sere Egelan —fetched
A trewereG eerl was ther nanG —truer none
Before the fyr so bryght.
From hym they token the rede scarlet,
Bothe hosynG and schoonG that weren hym met,N Ghose shoes suitable
That fel alG for a knyght.were appropriate
Nyne sytheG the bysschop halewidG the waytimes consecrated
That his weddyd brother scholde goo that day,
To praye God for the ryght.
He was unblemeschyd foot and hand;
That sawgh the lordes of the land,
And thankyd God of Hys myght.
They offeryd him with mylde chereGgentle bearing
Unto Saint PowlysG heyghe awtere,N GPaul’s altar
That mekyl was of myght.
Doun upon hys knees he felle,
And thankyd God that harewedeG helleharrowed
And Hys modyr so bryght.
And yit the bysschop thoG gan say:then
“Now schal the chyldryn gon the way
That the fadyr yede.”Gwent
Fro hem they tooke the rede scarlete,
The hosen and schoonG that weren hem mete,Gshoes fit
And al here worldly wede.Gclothes
The fyr was bothe hydousG and rede,hideous
The chyldryn swownyd asG they were ded;as if
The bysschop tyl hem yede;Gto them went
With careful herte on hem gan look;
Be hys hand he hem up took:
“Chyldryn, have ye no drede.”Gfear
Thanne the chyldryn stood and lowgh:Glaughed
“Sere, the fyr is cold inowgh.”
Thorwghout they wente apase.T Gquickly
They weren unblemeschyd foot and hand:
That sawgh the lordys of the land,
And thankyd God of His grace.
They offeryd hem with mylde chere
To Seynt Poulys hyghe awtere
This myracleG schewydN was there.miracle
And yit the bysschop efftG gan say:again
“Now schal the countasse goo the way
There that the chyldryn were.”
They fettenG forth the lady mylde;fetched
Sche was ful gret igon with chyldeGvery pregnant
In romaunce as we rede —
Before the fyr whan that sche come,
To Jesu Cryst he prayde a bone,N Gfavor
That leet His woundys blede:
“Now, God lat nevere the kyngys foo
QuykG out of the fyr goo.”Alive
Therof hadde sche no drede.
Whenne sche hadde maad here prayer,
Sche was brought before the feer,Gfire
That brennydG bothe fayr and lyght.burned
Sche wente fro the lengtheG into the thrydde;Gend third [ploughshare]
Stylle sche stood the fyr amydde,
And callyd it merye and bryght.
Hard schourysG thenne took here stronge[labor] pains
Bothe in bakG and ekeG in wombe;back also
And sithen it fell at syght.N
WhenneG that here paynys slakydG was,After pain abated
And sche hadde passydG that hydous pas,walk
Here nose barstG on bloode.burst
Sche was unblemeschyd foot and hand:
That sawgh the lordys of the land,
And thankyd God on Rode.GCross
They comaundyd men here away to drawe,Gmove away from here
As it was the landys lawe;N Glaw of the land (customary)
And ladyys thanne tyl here yode.Gto her went
She knelyd doun upon the ground
And there was born Seynt Edemound:N
Iblessed be that foode!Gchild
And whanne this chyld iborn was,
It was brought into the plas;N Gplace
It was bothe hoolG and soundwhole (healthy)
Bothe the kyng and bysschop freeGnoble
They crystnydG the chyld, that men myght see,christened

“Halff my land,” he sayde, “I thee geve,
AlsoG longe as I may leve,As
With markysG and with pounde;marks
And al afftyr my dedeG —death
Yngelond to wysseG and rede.”Gguide advise
Now iblessyd be that stounde!Gtime
Thanne sayde the bysschop to the Kyng:
“Sere, who made this grete lesyng,Glie
And who wroughte al this bale?”Gevil
Thanne sayde the kyng, “So moot I thee,Gthrive
That schalt thou nevere weteG for me,know
In burghG neyther in sale;Gtown hall
For I have sworn be Seynt AnneN
That I schal nevere bewreyeG that manne,betray
That me gan telle that tale.
They arnG savyd thorwgh thy red;Gare counsel
Now lat al this be ded,Gdead
And kepeG this counseyl hale.”Ghold (keep secret) entirely
Thenne swoor the bysschop, “So moot I the,Gthrive
Now I have power and dignyté
For to asoyleG thee as cleneGabsolve guiltless
As thou were hoven offG the fount-ston.N Glifted from baptismal font
Trustly troweG thou therupon,Truly believe
And holde it for no wene:Gguess
I swere bothe be book and belle,
But yiffG thou me his name telle,Unless
The ryght doomG schal I deme:Gjudgment pronounce
Thyselff schalt goo the ryghte way
That thy brother wente today,
Though it thee evele beseme.”Gill befits you
Thenne sayde the kyng, “So moot I the,Gthrive
Be schryffte of moutheG telle I it thee;By confession
Therto I am unblyve.Greluctant
Sertaynly, it is non othir
But Wymound, oure weddydG brother;sworn
He wole nevere thryve.”
“Allas,” sayde the bysschop than,
I wendeG he were the treweste man,thought
That evere yit levyd on lyve.
AndG he with this ateyntG may bee,If guilty
He schal be hongyd on trees three,
And drawen with horsG fyve.”N horses
And whenne that the bysschop the sotheG hadetruth
That that traytour that lesyngG made,lie
He callyd a messangere,
Bad hym to Dovere that he scholde founde,Ghasten
For to fetteG that Eerl Wymounde:fetch
(That traytour has no pere!)
SeyT Egelane and hys sones be slawe,
Bothe ihangyd and to-drawe.
(Doo as I thee lere!G)teach
The countasse is in presoun done;
Schal sche nevere out of presoun come,
But yiffG it be on bere.”GUnless bier
Now with the messanger was no badde;Gdelay
He took his hors, as the bysschop radde,Gcommanded
To Dovere tyl that he come.
The eerl in hys halle he fand:Gfound
He took hym the lettre in his hand
On hygh,G wolde he nought wone:GIn haste delay
“Sere Egelane and his sones be slawe,
Bothe ihangyd and to-drawe:
Thou getyst that eerldome.
The countasse is in presoun done;
Schal sche nevere more out come,
Ne see neyther sunne ne mone.”
Thanne that eerl made hym glade,
And thankyd God that lesyngG was made:lie
“It hath gete me this eerldome.”
He sayde, “Felawe, ryght weel thou bee!
Have here besauntysG good plentébesants (coins)
For thyn hedyr-come.”Gcoming hither
Thanne the messanger made his mon:Gcomplaint
“Sere, of youre goode hors lende me on:Gone
Now graunte me my bone;
For yystyrday deydeG my nobyl stede,died
On youre arendeN G as I yede,Gbusiness went
Be the way as I come.”
“Myn hors be fatte and cornfed,
And of thy lyff I am adred.”Ganxious
That eerl sayde to him than,
“Thanne yiff min hors sholde thee sloo,Gslay
My lord the kyng wolde be ful woo
To leseG swylkG a man.”lose such
The messanger yit he broughte a stede,
OnG of the beste at ylke a nedeGOne this very need
That evere on grounde dede gange,Ggo
Sadelyd and brydelyd at the beste.
The messanger was ful preste,Gready
WyghtlyG on hym he sprange.With agility
“Sere,” he sayde, “have good day;
Thou schalt come whan thou may;
I schal make the kyng at hande.”Gaware
With sporysG faste he strookG the stede;spurs struck
To GravysendeN he come good spede,
Is fourty myle to fande.Gtravel
There the messanger the traytour abood,Gawaited
And sethynG bothe insameG they rodthen together

In the palays there thay lyght;Galighted
Into the halle they come ful ryght,Gimmediately
And mette with Athelstone.
He wolde have kyssyd his lord swete.
He sayde: “Traytour, nought yit! lete!N G[allow] it not! desist!
Be God and be Seynt Jhon!GJohn
ForG thy falsnesse and thy lesyngBecause of
I slowgh myn heyr,G scholde have ben kyng,heir
When my lyf hadde ben gon.”
There he denyyd fasteG the kyng,strongly denied
That he made nevere that lesyng,Gever made that lie
Among hys peres alle.
The bysschop has hym be the hand tan;Gtaken
Forth insameG they are gantogether
Into the wyde halle.
Myghte he nevere with crafft ne gynne,Gtrick
Gare hym shryvenG of hys synne,Have himself absolved
For nought that myghte befalle.
Thenne sayde the goode Kyng Athelston:
“Lat hym to the fyr gon,
To preve the trewthe with alle.”T
Whenne the kyng hadde sayd soo,
A gret fyr was maad thoo,Gthen
In romaunce as we rede.
It was set, that men myghten knawe,
Nyne plowgh-lengeG on rawe,Glengths row
As red as ony glede.Gcoal

The wersG him gan to spede.Gworse happened
He wente fro the lengthe into the thrydde,
And doun he fell the fyr amydde:
Hys eyen wolde hym nought lede.Glead (guide)
Than the eerlys chyldryn were war ful smerte,Gfully aware
And wyghtlyG to the traytour sterte,Gquickly ran
And out of the fyr him hade;
And sworen bothe be book and belle:
“OrG that thou deye, thou schalt telleBefore
Why thou that lesyng made.”Gmade that lie
“Certayn, I can non otherG red,know no other
Now I wot I am but ded:Gnearly dead
I telle yow nothyng gladdeG —reluctantly (without joy)
Certayn, ther was non other wyte:Ginjury
He lovyd him to mekylG and me to lyte;Gmuch little
Therfore envye I hadde.”
Whenne that traytour so hadde sayde,
Fyve good hors to hym were tayde,Gtied
Alle menN myghten see with ygheG —eye
They drowenG him thorwgh ylkeG a strete,drew each
And sethynG to the Elmes,N I yow hete,Gthen assure
And hongyd him ful hyghe.
Was ther nevere man so hardy,Gbold
That durste felleG hys false body:dared take down
This hadde he for hys lye.
Now Jesu, that is Hevene-kyng,
Leve nevere traytour have betereG endyng,better
But swych domeG for to dye.judgment
